summary: a major factor in the host range of a coronavirus is its receptor utilization on host cells. fAPN serves as a functional receptor for most group 1 coronaviruses including feline infectious peritonitis virus (FIPV), canine coronavirus, transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) and human coronavirus 229E (HCoV-229E). the family of Coronaviridae is composed of group 1–3 coronaviruses. these viruses are able to infect human, canine, feline, murine, bovine, porcine, rat, and avian species. the etiological importance and zoonotic characteristics of coronaviruses have received much attention. group 1 coVs include human coronavirus-229E (HCoV-229E), feline infectious peritonitis virus (FIPV), transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV) and canine coronavirus (CCV) use human, feline, porcine, and canine aminopeptidase N (APN) as functional receptors during virus entry. feline APN (fAPN) was reported to allow entry of the IBV strain Arkansas 99 (IBV_Ark99) in the effort to identify the receptor for group 3 coVs. this could therefore be the first indication of a more universal receptor for the coV family. we cultured seven strains of IBV, including Arkansas 99,
